Reason: NFR 14 concerns web-server plug-ins and compatibility with Apache/Lighttp and web programming standards (WSGI, Servlet API). SRS 56 specifies Jhove plugin modules for identifying/validating WARC files. They do not share the same purpose, functionality, or requirements.
2ba2f55b-0d66-3e4b-92d8-46426b3742da:
no

Reasoning: NFR 16 is a cross‑platform portability requirement for the deliverables; SRS 69 specifies the development environment (develop on GNU/Linux, Fedora 7). They both mention platforms but serve different purposes and address different constraints, so they are not related.
5c87d63a-aac5-39e6-b7eb-20c17f45f9d9:
yes

Reason: Both specify that an API/library must enable functionality of the library in other environments (scriptable/bindable use in dynamic languages/Java), so they share purpose, similar functionality (language bindings/enablement), and overlapping constraints.
9b63e550-c45a-3064-8fbc-351b952c4495:
yes

Reasoning:
- Purpose: Both involve implementing functionality as web-server modules (specifically for Lighttp).
- Functionality: NFR 14 requires web-server plug-ins to operate correctly with Lighttp; SRS 40 specifies creating a Lighttp module (libwarc) to perform certain actions. Both concern module behavior within Lighttp.
- Requirements: NFR 14 imposes compatibility/API constraints that the Lighttp module specified in SRS 40 would need to meet, so they are related.
a27976c5-8bea-35a3-9572-aac5938ab3c8:
no

Reason: NFR 18 mandates designing the C library for SWIG-based language bindings (interoperability), while SRS 88 restricts use of external libraries in libwarc (dependency minimization). Their purposes, functionality targets, and specific constraints differ, so they are not related.
18283b04-905c-35dc-afe6-29a002073a97:
yes

Both target enabling Python-based WARC development: FR31 asks for a Python script to enable rapid WARC solution development, and SRS60 provides a Python interface to libwarc (via SWIG) which directly supports that goal and functionality.
70fa6fe9-be7c-3dec-b750-4017ba718e95:
yes

Reason: Both artifacts constrain/describe the implementation language and interoperability of the library. SRS 79 mandates implementation in C conforming to C99; NFR 18 requires the C library be developed so it can be wrapped by SWIG (which expects C/C++ interfaces). They address related implementation and compatibility requirements.
4a8c6d68-c693-3854-b0f7-32d1acdd9988:
yes

Both items concern exposing the library to other programming languages. NFR 21 requires language-appropriate exposure/idiomatic APIs for specific implementation languages; SRS 59 specifies providing SWIG-based interfaces to enable dynamic language bindings. They share the same purpose (language bindings/interop) and overlap in functionality and requirements (how the library is exposed to other languages), so they are related.
61e5bd0a-6426-333b-8efe-46d5fcbe0e44:
yes

Reason: Both concern the project's interaction with the open-source community. NFR 5 mandates ongoing communication and support for that community, while SRS 77 mandates releasing code/docs under an IIPC-approved open-source license. They address different specifics (service/support vs. licensing) but share the same overall purpose of enabling and governing community participation, so they are related.
ec5bc41b-bf4e-36c4-b032-079d917dbf0c:
yes

Both focus on the API: NFR 13 requires the API to enable functionality in specific libraries, and SRS 11 specifies the API's data and operations (ADT design) for Libwarc. They share purpose (defining API requirements), functionality (API capabilities), and requirements (constraints on how the API must expose data/operations).
e835e1fe-8385-3c81-b3a0-de0f9842de72:
yes

Rationale:
- Purpose: Both aim to provide a Python-facing interface to libwarc so Python programmers can use the library without C/internal knowledge.
- Functionality: Both specify providing a Python interface; the SRS specifies the implementation mechanism (SWIG) while the NFR states the need for such an interface.
- Requirements: They address the same requirement (exposing libwarc to Python), with the SRS giving a concrete implementation approach for the NFR.
4cbd5f04-8e15-3b11-90d7-5afd69c7d944:
yes

Reason: Both specify providing a Python interface to libwarc so Python users can access libwarc functionality. They share the same purpose (expose libwarc to Python), similar functionality (make libwarc features/API available in Python), and address the same requirement (Python-level access hiding C/internal details).
b76768ce-dd4d-3523-a1e8-ce9ba80d81a9:
yes

- Purpose: Both define how the library's functionality is made available to clients (the API/interface).
- Functionality: SRS 11 specifies the API's data and operations (ADTs); NFR 21 constrains how that API should be presented in different languages (idiomatic bindings). Both target the library interface.
- Requirements: They address related constraints on the API — SRS mandates abstract data types and operations, NFR mandates language-appropriate exposure — so they are related.
93f95376-8df3-3c2f-b850-ae6f83f32301:
yes

Reason: Both specify implementation-language constraints for the same component (WARC / libwarc). NFR 17 requires the API be coded in C with minimal dependencies and no assembly; SRS 79 requires implementation in C conforming to ANSI C99. They share the same purpose (defining implementation technology) and address overlapping requirements (language and implementation constraints), so they are related.
5048d941-bbc3-39b5-bbd6-d5296f9b1b4e:
yes

- Purpose: Both concern enabling functionality to run as a web-server plugin/module (operating within Apache).
- Functionality: SRS 39 specifies creating an Apache module (a web-server plug-in) to run libwarc actions; NFR 14 constrains how such plug-ins must be implemented (conform to Apache 'mod' API, work with Apache/Lighttp, follow WSGI/Servlet standards).
- Requirements: NFR 14 provides constraints that apply to the SRS 39 implementation (SRS 39 should satisfy the non‑functional compatibility/conformance requirements).
85d30b71-e53e-3856-87a8-34d2b833caec:
yes

Reason: Both concern how the library exposes functionality to clients (interfaces/APIs). NFR 21 focuses on presenting that functionality idiomatically for each implementation language, while SRS 6 focuses on ensuring those interfaces are stable/encapsulated so changes don’t break clients. They address related aspects of interface design (purpose and functionality), though they impose different specific constraints (idiomatic mapping vs. compatibility).
27858b29-2420-3d4b-b40a-9c2d81b9c5e1:
No

Reasoning:
- Purpose: Different — FR33 is about providing help/documentation for WARC-related command options; SRS45 is about implementing command-line tools to migrate HTTrack archives to WARC.
- Functionality: Different — one delivers help content for commands (curl, wget, httrack), the other performs actual data migration using libwarc.
- Requirements: Only loosely overlapping — both mention WARC and HTTrack, but they address different needs (documentation vs conversion functionality), so they are not directly related.
cb90f1e4-891f-3b80-97b9-6849e6257bf5:
yes

Reason: Both specify providing Python scripts to support WARC-based development. FR 31 states the high-level goal (make a Python script available to enable rapid WARC solution development), and SRS 51 refines that by requiring those scripts to incorporate libwarc and expose its API/functionality in Python. They share the same purpose, overlapping functionality, and aligned requirements (SRS 51 is a more detailed/implementation-level elaboration of FR 31).
86985e3d-cbf1-3276-b767-7d53ecb31cfb:
yes

Reasoning:
- Purpose: Both aim to make library functionality available to developers (NFR 12 via APIs and bindings; SRS 83 via released binary modules and libraries).
- Functionality: Both concern providing libraries (NFR 12 focuses on APIs and dynamic language bindings; SRS 83 specifies static/shared libraries and binaries). There is clear overlap in delivering library artifacts.
- Requirements: They address related constraints around supplying usable library artifacts, though SRS 83 adds build/release specifics (binary form, optimisation flags) while NFR 12 specifies bindings and API availability.
8193cea2-495e-30ef-b6b5-613c6e0d0ccb:
yes

- Purpose: Both aim to enable archived web content to be served and navigated correctly (supporting access/interface for archived resources).
- Functionality: Both deal with rewriting/transforming links and delivered content to make archived pages work (proxy-style vs client-side JavaScript rewriting are alternative mechanisms to achieve similar behavior).
- Requirements: Both address the requirement of providing an interface/mechanism for presenting archived content with modified links—different implementation approaches but the same overall concern.
f009a16b-0b69-3676-b6a3-330baee6bf9d:
yes

Reasoning:
- Purpose: Both aim to simplify use of libwarc by relying on a single header interface.
- Functionality: FR1 requires only one header be needed; SRS4 specifies that universal header "warc.h" provides cross-version compatibility — the universal header would be the single header FR1 mandates.
- Requirements: Both address the header-file constraint for consumers of libwarc and are therefore directly related.
